parts.title: Part 1: Short Conversations
parts.instruction: You will hear people talking in eight different situations. For questions 1-8, choose the best answer (A, B or C).

questions.audio_description: A woman is talking to her colleague about a meeting.
questions.transcript:
Woman: Did you hear? The marketing meeting has been moved from 2pm to 4pm. The director had a last-minute conflict with the original time.
Man: Oh, that's actually better for me. I have a client call at 2:30 that I was worried about.
Woman: Great. See you at four then.
questions.question: Why was the meeting time changed?

options.B: The man requested a later time.
options.C: The meeting room was not available.

questions.audio_description: You hear a weather forecast on the radio.
questions.transcript: Announcer: Good morning, listeners. Today we're looking at a mostly cloudy day with temperatures around 15 degrees. There's a 60% chance of rain in the afternoon, so don't forget your umbrella if you're heading out later. Tomorrow looks much better though, with sunshine expected throughout the day.
questions.question: What does the forecast say about tomorrow?

questions.audio_description: A customer is speaking to a shop assistant.
questions.transcript:
Customer: Excuse me, I bought this jacket last week, but when I got home I noticed this small tear near the pocket. I'd like to exchange it for the same one, please.
Assistant: I'm sorry about that. Do you have your receipt?
Customer: Yes, here it is.
questions.question: What is the customer's problem?

options.A: The jacket is the wrong size.
options.C: The jacket is the wrong color.

questions.audio_description: You hear a message on an answering machine.
questions.transcript: Hello, this is Dr. Patterson's office calling to confirm your appointment for Thursday at 10am. If you need to reschedule, please call us back at 555-0123 before Wednesday afternoon.
questions.question: What is the purpose of this call?

questions.audio_description: Two friends are discussing weekend plans.
questions.transcript:
Man: So, are you still coming to the barbecue on Saturday?
Woman: I'd love to, but I have to finish a report for Monday. I've been putting it off all week.
Man: That's too bad. Maybe we can meet up for coffee on Sunday instead?
Woman: That would be great. Let's say 2 o'clock at the usual place?
questions.question: Why can't the woman go to the barbecue?

options.C: She is going to a coffee shop.

questions.audio_description: A travel agent is giving information.
questions.transcript: Agent: The flight departs at 7:15 in the morning and arrives in Paris at 9:30 local time. You'll have a two-hour layover in Amsterdam. The total cost including taxes is $450.
questions.question: Where will the plane stop before Paris?

questions.audio_description: A professor is making an announcement.
questions.transcript: Professor: Before we end today's class, I want to remind everyone that the deadline for the research paper has been extended by one week. It's now due on the 25th instead of the 18th. However, I still encourage you to submit early if you can.
questions.question: What has the professor announced?

questions.audio_description: A woman is talking about her new job.
questions.transcript: Woman: I started my new job last Monday. The office is only a 10-minute walk from my apartment, which is so much better than my hour-long commute before. The work is challenging but interesting.
questions.question: What does the woman like about her new job?

parts.title: Part 2: Gap Fill
parts.instruction: You will hear a talk about the history of coffee. For questions 9-14, complete the sentences with ONE word.
parts.audio_description: A lecturer giving a talk about the history of coffee.
parts.transcript:
Good afternoon, everyone. Today I'm going to talk about the fascinating history of coffee.

The story of coffee begins in Ethiopia, where, according to legend, a goat herder named Kaldi noticed his goats becoming energetic after eating berries from a certain tree.

From Ethiopia, coffee spread to the Arabian Peninsula. By the 15th century, coffee was being grown in Yemen. Coffee houses, known as qahveh khaneh, began to appear in cities throughout the Middle East.

Europeans first encountered coffee in the 17th century when Venetian traders brought it to Italy.

The Dutch were the first Europeans to establish coffee plantations in their colonies, starting in Java, Indonesia.

Today, coffee is the second most traded commodity in the world after oil. The largest producer of coffee is Brazil.

questions.question: According to legend, coffee was discovered by a _____ herder.
Coffee originated in the country of _____.
By the 15th century, coffee was being grown in _____.
Coffee was first brought to Europe by _____ traders.
The Dutch established plantations in _____, Indonesia.
The largest coffee producer in the world is _____.

parts.title: Part 3: Speaker Matching
parts.instruction: You will hear four people talking about learning a foreign language. For questions 15-18, match each speaker with the correct statement (A-F).
parts.audio_description: Four people talking about learning a foreign language.

speakers.name: Speaker 1
speakers.transcript: When I moved to Spain for work, I was forced to learn Spanish quickly. The best thing I did was completely immerse myself - I stopped watching English TV and only listened to Spanish radio.

speakers.name: Speaker 2
speakers.transcript: I tried so many language apps and courses, but what really worked for me was finding a language exchange partner. We meet twice a week - one day we speak only German, the next only English.

speakers.name: Speaker 3
speakers.transcript: Grammar books and vocabulary lists never worked for me. I learned French by watching French films with French subtitles. It was entertainment and education at the same time.

speakers.name: Speaker 4
speakers.transcript: The biggest mistake I made was being afraid to speak. I spent years perfecting my written Japanese but couldn't hold a conversation. Now I force myself to speak, even if I make mistakes.

options.A: suggests that making mistakes is part of learning
options.C: believes total immersion is the most effective method
options.D: thinks traditional learning methods are best
options.E: values the social aspect of language learning
options.F: believes language learning requires expensive courses

parts.title: Part 4: Map Labeling
parts.instruction: You will hear a guide describing a university campus. For questions 19-24, match each place with the correct letter (A-H) on the map.
parts.audio_description: A guide describing a university campus tour.
parts.transcript: Welcome to our university campus tour. Let me show you around. If you look straight ahead, you'll see the Main Library - that's the large building right in the center. To the left of the library is the Science Building, and right behind it is the Sports Center. If you turn right from the entrance, the first building you see is the Student Union. The Cafeteria is just next to the Student Union. And finally, the Art Gallery is the small building at the far end of the campus, near the lake.

parts.title: Part 5: Multiple Choice
parts.instruction: You will hear an interview with a marine biologist. For questions 25-30, choose the best answer (A, B or C).
parts.audio_description: An interview with Dr. Sarah Chen, a marine biologist.
parts.transcript:
Interviewer: Today we're joined by Dr. Sarah Chen, a marine biologist who has spent the last fifteen years studying ocean ecosystems.

Dr. Chen: Thank you for having me.

Interviewer: How would you describe the current state of our oceans?

Dr. Chen: Our oceans are in crisis. We're seeing coral bleaching events more frequent than ever. Fish populations are declining due to overfishing. And perhaps most concerning is the plastic pollution problem.

Interviewer: What do you think is the biggest threat?

Dr. Chen: Climate change. Rising ocean temperatures cause coral bleaching, change fish migration patterns, and as oceans warm they absorb more carbon dioxide, making them more acidic.

Interviewer: What can ordinary people do?

Dr. Chen: Support policies that protect marine areas. That's the most impactful thing.

Interviewer: Are there success stories?

Dr. Chen: When we protect areas properly, nature can recover remarkably quickly.

Interviewer: What's next for your research?

Dr. Chen: Mapping microplastic distribution in the Pacific Ocean.

questions.question: How long has Dr. Chen been studying ocean ecosystems?
What does Dr. Chen consider the biggest threat?
What happens when oceans absorb more CO2?
What is the most impactful action for people?
What does Dr. Chen say about protected areas?
What is Dr. Chen's current research about?

parts.title: Part 6: Note Completion
parts.instruction: You will hear a talk about healthy eating habits. For questions 31-36, complete the notes with ONE word.
parts.audio_description: A nutritionist giving a talk about healthy eating habits.
parts.transcript:
Today I want to share some simple tips for healthier eating. First, always eat a good breakfast - studies show it improves your concentration throughout the morning. Second, try to include protein in every meal, such as chicken, fish, or beans.

Drinking enough water is essential - aim for at least eight glasses per day. Many people confuse thirst with hunger.

When it comes to snacking, choose fruit or nuts instead of processed foods. Also, try to cook at home more often rather than ordering takeaway. Home-cooked meals typically contain less salt and sugar.

Finally, don't skip meals. Regular eating maintains your energy levels and prevents overeating later in the day.

questions.question: A good breakfast improves your _____ throughout the morning.
You should include _____ in every meal.
You should drink at least eight _____ of water per day.
For snacks, choose fruit or _____ instead of processed foods.
Home-cooked meals typically contain less salt and _____.
Regular eating prevents _____ later in the day.
